conclusion: Analysis of Acceleration Ratio During Deceleration Phases
Looking at the velocity-time graph for particles A and B, I'll analyze their acceleration during the deceleration phases.
Particle A: Decelerates from point A (at time t₀) to the time axis at 3t₀
Particle B: Decelerates from point B (at time 5t₀) to the time axis at 6t₀
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, which is the slope of the v-t graph.
Initial velocity at point A: 2v₀ (at time t₀)
Final velocity for particle A: 0 (at time 3t₀)
Initial velocity at point B: v₀ (at time 5t₀)
Final velocity for particle B: 0 (at time 6t₀)

premise: Taking the magnitudes (removing the negative signs since we're asked for the ratio of magnitudes): |Acceleration of A| = v₀/t₀, |Acceleration of B| = v₀/t₀

conclusion: The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for particles A and B during their deceleration phases is 1:1 or simply 1.
